reviewText: Having 47 Madonna Video's in a collection is what I have been Praying for years ago! The dream finally came true.On this collection you can find videos unavailable on any previous releases by Madonna and it's really worth it to see those videos in a chronological order and see how one of the biggest stars of our time has evolved in her artistic, controversial yet charming videos.

reviewText: Celebration: The Video Collection by Madonna contains 47 groundbreaking music videos from the Queen of Pop. Of course not all of Madge's fabulous videos are included like: This Used to be My Playground, Bad Girl, Nothing Really Matters, You Must Love Me, Oh Father, and Drowned World. Overall, I think this collection is great - I had no problem with the picture quality or audio. Frozen is my favorite Madonna video of all-time! She looked so gorgeous and tranquil in that video. I am glad to have Erotica and Justify My Love in this collection even though some parts are censored. No matter how terrible I am feeling, Madge can put a smile on my gloomy face. Long live the Queen!!!

reviewText: Along with theCelebration (2 CD) REMASTEREDrelease, Warner Bros. Music also released Madonna's third music video collection on DVD. This set contains 2 DVD with 47 music videos spanning Madonna's 26 years in the music business. There are a lot of reviews of this product complaining of the quality of the video. Off hand, the first disc that contains her earliest videos ("Burning Up", "Lucky Star", "Borderline" for example) aren't the best quality. In fact, I felt that these videos were almost identical to the quality of the videos released on her first music video DVD,Madonna - The Immaculate Collection. I could only detect a slight different in the quality, but the older the video, the lower the quality it seemed to be. This did disappoint me a bit since the sticker on the front of the product boasts "digitally re-mastered from the original tapes!" Was this statement referring to the videos or the music tracks? As with many of the music tracks and edits from the 'Immaculate Collection' being placed on the CD edition of 'Celebration' I am feeling pretty confident that Warner Bros. lazily dropped the same videos (not remastered, not retouched, not enhanced) from theMadonna - The Immaculate CollectionandMadonna - Video Collection 1993-99. It was a rather misleading statement on Warner Bros. part to lead the consumer to think every video contained on these 2 DVDs were going to be digitally restored and polished, looking better than ever. The only videos that really leaped off the screen were the newest ones (Disc 2 for the most part). That is a major point of criticism for me that keeps this from being a true 5-star product.The Good: I felt the DVD edition's strength is that it succeeds in acknowledging her entire career in some manner where as the CD companion (even the 2 CD edition) skipped around and left out many of the ballads, soundtrack hits and blurred the lines with what was a true hit and what may have been chosen by Warner Bros. just to fill disc space. It was a surprise that music videos of so many songs, even songs that were not true 'hits', made it onto the DVD. Seeing videos "True Blue", "Into the Groove", "Deeper and Deeper", "I'll Remember", "Love Profusion" (to name a few) included made me feel the DVD definitely got more attention and is worth the money because of all the music and videos, diversity and mix of well-known and lesser-known tracks, this was a true 'celebration' of Madonna's career rather than just another ploy from Warner Bros. music to make money off of Madonna before she moves on to Live Nation. While the quality of the videos on Disc 1 left much to be desired, I felt Disc 2 great in quality and probably worth the purchase alone. This disc contains videos from the 'Music' era through 'Hard Candy' and even the video for "Celebration". This is where the last video collection left off and definitely is a nice buy for any Madonna fan who wants the videos of the 2000s all on DVD. These, unlike her earlier videos on Disc 1, are definitely high quality. Overall, I did not experience any of the pixelation issues or distorted picture that some reviews mentioned because my TV is not huge and isn't HD or fancy. I was pleased with the audio on both discs and felt the videos (with the exception of the first 8 on Disc 1) were either good or very stunning ("Rain" for example was very bright and vibrant, the colors in "You'll See" and "Jump" were rich and stunning).The Bad: As with the CD version, I was perplexed with some of the omissions. I understand Warner Bros. attempt to create a product that doesn't completely render the past two DVD collections pointless and not worth buying, but this is supposed to be some of Madonna's most iconic videos all in one set. It is supposed to be a 'celebration' of her great music video work and imagery, celebrating her artistic and visual performer side over the music. Why, I ask, did Warner Bros. leave off the cinematic video for "Bad Girl", or the most drastic re-invention/character she's ever played in a video, being the geisha in the video for "Nothing Really Matters"? Also, this would have been a great opportunity to showcase the original video for "American Life" that's been floating around the internet for years now. Also, some of these soundtrack videos are simply unnecessary. "I'll Remember", "Crazy for You", "Who's That Girl" are all great songs but c'mon, the videos are nothing more than clips from the movies. Those could have been eliminated to make room for the missing videos, or even iconic live performances (the 'Like a Virgin' 1984 performance, VMA 'Vogue' performance, the earth-shattering Britney/Madonna kiss). Some of the videos from her tours could have even been included as they are almost better than some of the official music videos. While I was glad to see "Justify My Love" and "Erotica" both included, Warner's choice to censor them with tacky black boxes over breasts and naughty bits just seemed tacky. We are all aware of these videos and what's being hidden; adults (for the most part) are buying the product. Stick a 'parental advistory' sticker on it and give the fans the full, unedited versions! The flaws struck me as laziness and business decisions made by Warner, not Madonna, to make a buck, save some time and grief and avoid controversy at all costs (being creativity and a quality product). I'm pretty sure Madonna herself had no hand in this since she's not a fan of the whole 'greatest hits' idea to begin with.In all, due to the nice spread of videos and both hit and lesser-known tracks, I definitely feel this is worth the purchase. Yes, there are flaws and this is by all means not a perfect product. Yet, I still feel this DVD collection is for the fans. If anything, we now (across 3 releases) have almost all of Madonna's videos on DVD. If the edited and watered-down CD release of 'Celebration' left a lot to be desired, I say put your money into this product. You'll not only get the music, but you'll get the videos to go along with them and that, in my opinion, is the 'definitive' and complete Madonna experience.
Title: N/A

reviewText: As a late Madonna fan, I watched this dvd selection of her videos in awe!I'm so glad she included Justify my Love and Erotica, but they are edited a bit, and someone as strong in her opinions as Madonna, I thought, would see this asa disappointment, since she enjoys pushing the limits, especially re: SEX, Ialso loved the video where she is showing her real self for the first time in LIKE A VIRGIN! It always brings back great memories of when I was going to dance clubsmainly in Hollywood, many re-mixes of that song..I wish she included Gambler,and the Thunderpussy video, that shows almost all her videos in clips.FROZEN is an incredible video meaning different things to different people, that video shows her other side I feel, that's why she's all in blk,she really feels in that video.The video, Human Nature,is another fave of mine, very disappointed that the song was edited, it's not like the video that expresses much more, when she says certain words that fit the video and song, and at the end she has a laugh on us, as in the end of Justify My love, where she is laughing at the end, in the hotel hall..I can't understand why HOLIDAY was not on the videos either, one of her famous funsongs..or Sooner or later where her range is different, would have loved a video for that song, and PLEASE LOVE ME, KEEP IT TOGETHER, are other songs that should have been on video..in this collection..For Madonna's look back though, I gave it four stars because of some of the videos she included, but I feel Madonna herself didn't have as much say on this collectionas would have been, if they were all on her own label, and  the videos wouldn'tbe edited at all.I missed LOVE DON'T LIVE HERE ANYMORE too..This collection reminded me of when her book, SEX just came out, and was a big hit everywhere, still is!Sadly, my friend who died of Aids, left that book to me, and I think of him when I see it..he adored all her videos too! She has made so many people accept themselves for what they really are, so they can be real to themselves..She left out one of her first dance songs too, EVERYBODY, she really looks so different in those baggy pants and vest,A very young Madonna..The Madonna of today, is so well fashionable she changes with every tour, and sometimes with every new song, that's the secret to her being a true DIVA! Only Cher has accomplished that..These videos all show her independance, the video, EXPRESS YOURSELF, allowed some women for the first time to feel their power,equal to men, sexually when she seems to always get what she wants, esp. that gorgeous guy in that video..who is in the Vogue video too.The video of Deeper and Deeper, one of my faves,she really looks like a flower child, and when they did that photo shoot in the video, it shows another new look for her..the banana scene is so funny, I loved that scene..Madonna has a great sense of humor..I'm amazed that Madonna is probably the best woman around,in her decade, that has the energy for all those videos, just watching Rain, is so visually fantastic, whoever directed that video had an eye to show Madonna at her best.I highly recommend this dvd collection, it's a great look back at Madonna's vast worksince the eighties..and beyond.Toni Nason

reviewText: Yup, that's right, never been a Madonna fan. I'm a big Kylie (Minogue) fan here. Now, I'm no Madonna hater, I've always thought Madonna's hits were catchy, but just was never a fan and never bought any of her albums. So why do I give this DVD 5 stars? I collect music DVD's of female artists, even those I'm not a fan of. If I find there music catchy, I'll get it. Because I never followed Madonna's music I never knew this DVD existed since 2009. Because of this DVD, I didn't have to go and purchase multiple DVD's to get all her video's. Ignore the bad reviews on here of people complaining bad picture, bad sound, bad this, bad that, censored version this, censored version that. People can be so picky about the littlest things, the picture on this is very watchable, and the 5.1 surround is awesome! This DVD is 5 stars all the way for packing 47 of Madonna's biggest hits in one DVD!
summary: I'm Not Even A Madonna Fan...And I Give This 5 Stars

reviewText: The concept was good: release 47 of Madonna's videos many for the first time in one package. The delivery was the problem. At over three hours spread over two single layer discs we get Madonna overload. This is not necessarily a bad thing because she has provided much of the pop culture soundtrack  over the last three decades. The problem here is the video and sound quality.The single layer discs do nothing for the picture quality of the videos. Many of them probably looked better in their original VHS format and the supposed Dolby 5.1 sountrack is also lacking in depth and power. Perhaps the greatest flaw with this set is that there is overt censoring on two of the most controversial videos (Justify My Love and Erotica. I remember when the songs came out and were available on VHS without the censoring and now almost 20 years later we are treated to black bars.On the upside we do get some of the best and earliest works by some pioneer video directors. The videos showed a style that would be copied over the years over and over. Madonna was and is the standard setter for an entire generation of followers and her video collection deserved a much better treatment than it got in this Warner Brothers release.
summary: Not As Good As It Should Have Been
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a collection of 47 of Madonna's music videos spread over two DVDs with a running time of approximately 3 1/2 hours. This is more expansive than the thirty-six track CD counterpart. One of my issues with the CD version, asides from the unexpected track edits, is the non-chronological sequencing which makes hearing her artistic progression impossible. Thankfully the video collection are presented in order from earliest to most recent. The viewer, the fan is treated to a fascinating journey through Madonna's career, as her look and sound changes and evolves. While it would have been nice if this collection contained ALL of her music videos, the selection is more than generous. For those who grew up in the 1980s and 1990s listening to her, there's a healthy dose of nostalgia involved in watching these videos. And it should without saying that she has maintained a high level of commercial success right up to present day. I give this collection a 5-star rating.

reviewText: Inarguably the greatest singles artist of the last quarter century, Madonna was also no slouch in the video department either, as this generous, if incomplete, 47 track collection attests to.  The first thing that sticks out for me is the tracklisting itself, which manages to skip over some highly essential Madonna videos--"Oh Father", "Bad Girl"(probably her worst single EVER but a gorgeous video), "Fever", "Drowned World/Substitute For Love" and "Nothing Really Matters", all represented on previous video compilations, are absent here and considering that the former two are two of the most artistically stunning videos ever filmed gives one pause as to why they didn't see the light of day on this collection; I find it hard to believe they couldn't have somehow been squeezed on to this  set. Also, as many have pointed out, an edited "Justify My Love" appears--at this juncture, there really doesn't seem to be any reason to even include it if it isn't the original, unedited version.  Also absent is either version of "American Life"(probably Madonna's SECOND WORST single ever), but again it would have been nice for completion's sake. As for the picture quality, I'll agree it's not optimum though the sound quality here is absolutely fantastic.  Overall, considering there was room for 47 videos, it would have been nice to see at least three of the aforementioned tacked on for good measure but as such this is as complete as you're going to get in one place.
summary: Overall An Excellent If Incomplete Collection

reviewText: All of the people saying that the fans are overreacting either work for Warner Brothers, are not detail-oriented people, or are very, VERY easily pleased. And to everyone saying "they are old videos from the 80's, of course they won't look perfect", that is NOT an excuse. If they can make The Wizard OF Oz and Gone With The Wind look the way they do, they can make a few videos from only 25 years ago look AMAZING. There are NO excuses, NO if's, NO and's, NO butt's. THERE IS NO WAY TO JUSTIFY THE SLOPPY editing work on this release. "I Want You" is particularly devastating as this beautiful video looks like it was taken straight from youtube. "Burning Up" and "Lucky Star" are also particularly grainy, with "Lucky Star" looking completely washed out and worse than it appeared on the Immaculate Collection DVD. I will be fair, some of the videos look ok, I've only skimmed through the DVD so far, but I remember "Material Girl", and most of the newer videos looking decent. The sound on "Papa Don't Preach" is flawed, there are several instances of static throughout the video. And now we get to "Justify My Love". It is censored. Not to mention, Warner Bros. stated in their OFFICIAL PRESS RELEASE (Official! Not speculation, not a rumor, not a "maybe", an OFFICIAL STATEMENT on Madonna's OFFICIAL WEB SITE) that "Justify  My Love" would contain unedited and previously unreleased footage. That footage is no where to be seen. It wouldn't make me mad if they hadn't promised it in the first place. And the fact that they ended up CENSORING it makes it even more of a slap in the face in addition to a BOLD FACED LIE. Why would Madonna allow this? The 1990 VHS single sold thousands of copies in its original version, and this comes from a woman who went on Nightline on ABC back in 1990 and DEFENDED this video to the nation. I miss that Madonna.I'm tempted to give the DVD 3 stars but I just can't. The only way I can give it 2 is because I have loved Madonna since I was a kid and her videos are amazing. How could one of the biggest music video visionaries, not to mention the most famous female pop star in the world, not have a justifiable and complete video archive of her work, especially now that she is ending her long run with Warner?? it boggles my mind and it makes me more mad the more I think about it, especially since this is probably the last Madonna collection we are going to get anytime soon. Unfortunately, WB probably won't do Madonna any justice with her work until she's dead.Are the videos unwatchable? No. (except maybe for "I Want You"). They are just barely OK. just BARELY. If you are a Madonna fan, you have to have it. Do i sound bitter? HELL YES. And we have a right to be. We have been fans for YEARS and this whole project was not handled professionally. Don't even get me started on the errors on the CD version.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I will start out by writing that I don't believe it was necessary for WB to include the censored version of Justify My Love in this collection.As for the other videos in the collection, I enjoyed the earlier videos more than the later ones. The older ones have more depth and substance to them, IMO.Many of the videos were filmed in NYC and show off the famous skyline. These videos brought back a lot of memories. They feature some great performances, too.Papa Don't Preach, is one of those videos that has great character development for a music video. Most of the earlier videos featured are more like short films than an average music video. Madonna seemed to work with the best directors at the time.I would have liked to have seen the American Life video included in the collection. Overall, the collection is good, yet the packaging feels limited and lacks a polished presentation.The DVD menu is dull, yet it serves its function. The viewer can choose to play all the videos or select a video to play. The audio is clear in both stereo and surround sound. The video quality varies.Most of the videos featured are entertaining. Some are thought provoking. A few would easily make any, "best videos ever made" list.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Of course we all know that Madonna is a shapeshifter. But this DVD really refreshed my memory on the enormity of this matron-of-pop's creative scope.I lament the absence of Bad Girl, which is one of my favorites. A video that moved me and carried an emotional gravity that some of the other included-tracks lack. Also it is a shame Fever never made the cut. I regard Erotica as being the zenith of her creative career and I bemoan the fact  that two videos from that period were cut. AND it is galling that the Erotica and Justify My Love videos, whose very premises were to provoke, have been censored by clumsy black bars.What's left is a still impressive albeit occasionally disposable (see 2nd half of 2nd disc) collection. And while the quality is not excellent, it is nice having the majority of her body of work available outside of the constraints of youtube. Three stars.

reviewText: Why wouldn't an artist that truly loves and respects her fans NOT include ALL the videos from her career?  I can understand not including "live" re-edits (Dress You Up, Gambler, etc) but leaving out MAJOR moments in your career is silly.  This set is only 4 tracks away from near perfection.  The Pet Shop Boys made the BEST DVD set I have ever seen back in 03 with PopArt. It included ALL videos up to that point, plus commentary on all (even at their own expense), three extra tracks, as well as a shuffle option.  All that on ONE disc. I sometimes feel like Madonna wants us to buy everything just so she can laugh at us while we flip flop between DVD's and CD's JUST to get ALL of her hits at once.  I have loved her for years but I just don't like the marketing anymore, it feels like she couldn't care less if she has fans. Maybe it's the marketing company, maybe not, either way it's annoying. Who knows, maybe we will be graced with easter eggs on this set and I will happily be made a fool of.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Despite the haters, this is easily the most iconic and impressive video collection since Michael Jackson released his.  You get 47 videos here across 2 DVD's.  I think it was unusually generous to include 11 videos for songs that weren't on the Celebration album!  True, like the album there are some songs conspicuously absent (most painfully obvious is "American Life"), but this set will not disappoint...too much...more on that later.The video quality, for the most part, is good.  I played it on a PlayStation 3 (upscaling via HDMI) on a 40" Sony Bravia XBR HDTV.  With the exception of a 4 or 5 videos on disc 2, the video looked really good and I noticed no pixelation.  The sound options on the DVD include 5.1 surround, but that's a joke.  Still, even though it's just a slightly enhanced stereo mix, it's very clear and I have no complaints.As far as content, there are some fantastic moments here.  For the first time on home video, we're treated to videos such as "Into the Groove", "Crazy for You", "Who's That Girl", "Erotica", "Deeper and Deeper", "I Want You", "You'll See", "Don't Tell Me" among others.  Plus, we get a video for "Miles Away" that has been released and practically never seen before, and we get the video for "Celebration".  Also, "Get Together" is included, but it's the alternate version, which is nice to see.  One glaring drawback is that the "Justify My Love" video does not feature any new footage despite what the DVD label says, and it does edit one scene (it shows black bars blocking a woman's breasts).  Not sure why they did that, but it's not cool.  Black bars are also present on the last scene of the "Erotica" video, but that's the way it's always been shown.All in all, this is well worth it despite it's one or two flaws.  You will never get a more impressive collection of truly groundbreaking videos ever.  Madonna has truly revolutionized the music video medium and it certainly shows here.  Fans of Madonna should not pass this up.

reviewText: This is a type of release that makes a quick buck for Warner, nothing more really. The quality is incredibly poor, it makes the whole thing look cheap, even the cover looks cheap. Why they didn't use double layered dvd's is beyond me!!! It's such a shame. Everything looks pixelated and very poor. Celebrating Madonna's years in the business and what we get is this! Even the release of the earlier dvd's and videos are in much better quality than this. I am sooo disappointed with this. It's not a thank you to the fans, it's more like a f*** you. And forget the 5.1 sound, there is no such thing on this collection. They also managed to put a black sticker in Justify My Love, nice "extra footage" that was promised - was that it?!! When this video (JML) was released in 1990 it had no sticker on it and it was in much better quality than this. OMG Warner, you've shot yourself in the foot. Thank God Madonna has left you. But I can also say that she should have had more of a hand in this than she did. I don't think there was much from her side on this.

reviewText: I wanted this video collection as it covers almost every video Madonna ever did, not all but most.  I read the negative reviews here and decided not to get it.After a few weeks I read more of the reviews and realized that most of the negative reviews were from blu ray owners.  THIS IS NOT A BLU RAY DISC PEOPLE!  Its a DVD!!!Anyone should realize that if they have a 1080p high def tv and a blu ray or upscaled dvd player that most dvds will not look very good.  1080p is a BLU RAY display device, made for high def discs-NOT DVD!I played a few of the videos last night on my five year old Sony lcd projection 720p tv last night and the sound/pictures are EXCELLENT!!  Very clear and smooth images free of any problems.Perhaps with all the upset 1080p folks Warner will release a blu ray of this collection.  Im sure they just wanted this collection to be perfect, like the rest of us who love Madonna- a passionate bunch.
summary: No problems for us dvd folks!

reviewText: Besides Michael Jackson (may he rest in peace) there was no other artist besides Madonna that is as controversial, world-renowned, successful as a solo entertainer and known for not only her formative and innovational music-videos but for helping to invent the entire music-video genre, while also putting MTV on the map at the same time. With the appearance in her first music-video in 1980 (dancing backup to Patrick Hernandez in his club classic, the disco sensation "Born to Be Alive") over the last 30 years Madonna has appeared in more music-videos than any other entertainer, singer, performer, mother, woman, human being and dancing-queen. Through her videos Madonna not only defined a generation but also caused her viewers to question their own existence, importance and relevance. What child of the MTV generation does not remember the Madonna video marathons that they used host on a nearly monthly basis? Her videos were and are fascinating because like the star herself, they were all highly produced, over-the-top, dramatic, beautiful, sexy and very enigmatic.Madonna has been the reigning Queen of Pop for 26 years (her debut album "Madonna" came out in the summer of '83) and Warner Bros. Records has decided to release this 2 disc DVD set, aptly titled "Celebration" in conjunction with Madonna's greatest hits CD by the same title. It's hard to believe that the most successful female entertainer in the entire world who has had more music-videos in rotation on MTV than any other artist only has 2 other video compilations (1990's "The Immaculate Collection" and the considerably less in your face, "The Video Collection 93:99" that came out at the end of the 20th century.) "Celebration" is a much needed shot of dance, entertainment and fun for both Madonna's gaggle of fans and for the casual listener of popular dance."Celebration" will include some of Madonna's most nonpareiled, short form music-videos. These videos are exclusive to this collection, having never been released on any other Madonna compilation yet:1. Into The Groove2. Who's That Girl3. True Blue4. Justify My Love5. Erotica6. American Pie7. Music8. Don't Tell Me9. What It Feels Like for a Girl10. Day Another Day11. Hollywood12. Love Profusion13. Hung Up14. Sorry15. Get Together16. Jump17. 4 Minutes18. Give It 2 Me19. Miles Away19. CelebrationYears ago the status symbol that said that pop stars had arrived was getting their video banned from MTV. It not only showed that they were not afraid to write their own rules, but it also showcased an entirely new form of art that everyone wanted to take part in. Today, about the only thing that these no-talent celebrities can do is walk around without any undergarments on and hope that their picture gets up on the net.Although her "Papa Don Preach" video was very controversial for its time (because to some it polarized teen pregnancy, while others felt that she was not giving "modern" girls of the '80s the right to choose) MTV did not ban it. Instead, the music-video peaked at #1 all over the world and became Madonna's very first video single. In 1989 with the release of "Like a Prayer" Madonna almost got her long overdue wish. Although it was not banned in the US (MTV showed it every hour and every day for more than 3 consecutive months), it was banned on state-run Italian TV. Her next video, "Express Yourself" was at the time the most expensive short form ever produced. In this musical film we can see Madonna crawling on a floor, making love to a factory worker, pouring a white viscous liquid over her shoulder and watching a group of half naked men fight for her affections. However she didn't get her first banned video until the following year with "Justify My Love."For "Justify My Love" Madonna booked up an entire floor at Parisian hotel to host a lavish sex orgy on film. Nothing was off limits, taboo, too risky or too vivid for the imagination. When the video was banned Madonna got Warner Video to release it onto home-video, making it the most successful video single in the entire history of the world while simultaneously making shop-lifters out of 10 year-olds all over the world who wanted to sneak a peak at this racy video. On the night of the premiere of "Erotica" MTV showed an entire block of Madonna videos, complete with trivia and news about her upcoming record and book of se'Xx'ual fantasies. When the video premiered at midnight Kurt Lorder introduced it saying, "What you are about to see is the music-video by arguably the most famous person in the world, this video depicts sexual acts between consenting adults. Some are not bothered by this, others are repelled by this. That is why MTV is not showing this video during regular rotation."Throughout the mid '90s Madonna produced a core of extraordinarily cutting edge videos that are perhaps some of the very best of her entire career. In "Take a Bow" we see a thought-out love story involving a woman of the '40s and a Spanish bullfighter, the plot picked up a year later with Madonna's follow-up video "You'll See." In "Bedtime Story" Madonna takes us all on futuristic trip inside her mind. She shows her frustration in "Human Nature" and her softer side in "I Want You," "You Must Love Me" and "Love Don't Live Here Anymore." Perhaps one of Madonna's most mesmerizing videos of the '90s was her second VHS single, "Ray of Light" which also became one of her many signatures hits.In the very first time of her career, Madonna used fast moving cinematography that showcased her darker side and caused some to wonder why she had so much anger and rage built up in "What It Feels Like for a Girl." After MTV showed the video once and then withdrew it from their regular rotating schedule Madonna released it as a video single (her second DVD single, since the avant-garde "Music"). Three years later in another first, Madonna showed a sense of decency, contrite and even respect by choosing to withdraw "American Life." Again Madonna's driving factor is no longer sexual imagery and personal fantasy, but rage, degradation and violence. In this clip Madonna skyjacks a fashion show as she holds everyone hostage. When the video was edited and redistributed to music channels around the US many were stunned. This time because Madonna wasn't nearly as outrageous or offensive or vulgar as before (she was only seen singing in front of an array of international flags).Madonna went back to her roots in "Hung Up," performing in a retro pink leotard in a dance studio. She played the same part in the video that followed ("Sorry") which was again shocking for many to see. Not because Madonna was obscene or vulgar or undressing for the camera. This time no one could believe how youthful Madonna appeared, like she were 20 years younger. But no matter what she does, has done or will do Madonna shocks; it's a habit!Recently I had the pleasure of speaking with a very successful entertainer and one of the most famed VJ's who was on MTV during the height of Madonna's popularity. We spoke about a lot of things but mostly about why Madonna's managed to remain so influential over the years. It is because like MTV, Madonna knew how to change with the times and "re-invent" herself with each passing year as her audience of listeners and viewers also changed. Unlike a host of other superstars of the past, Madonna learned early on that if she wanted to remain important and on the cutting edge she would have to keep her finger on not only what's commercial and what's successful but also on what's the biggest and the best. And, over the last several years since MTV stopped showing music-videos Madonna has even transcended a network that once encompassed her.Madonna has done it all. She's been everything from a hooker to a missionary. And her videos have depicted all of her personas, nuances, fads, fashion transgressions, inner demons and retrogressions. So many of us idolized Madonna because she was the voice for the voiceless. We identified with her because not only was she speaking her mind honestly and artistically through her music and her videos, but she was also pushing the envelope in both an artistic and nonconforming manner. Who else besides Madonna could make it cool to sing on a traditional gondola, perform in a peep show, dance in front of burning crosses, show a close-up of a deceased person's stitched mouth, be chained to a bed, throw a grenade at the most powerful man in the free world or go hitchhiking in the nude?No one else has that blatant nerve or inner desire to not only top herself, but to exceed the expectations of all of her contemporaries and protractors. They say fame is a very fleeting thing, but Madonna's legacy will live on forever, immortalized in her music-videos.

reviewText: Before anyone gets on my case, I HAVE THE DVD and am watching it right now.Let me start off on a positive note, the DVD set contains 47 videos on 2 DVDs. Some good ones are inexplicably omitted (Dress You Up, Oh Father, Bad Girl, Fever, This Used to Be My Playground, Substitute For Love, Nothing Really Matters, American Life, etc)  but there is a lot of good material released here for the first time. The audio is generally excellent. The 5.1 track is not really a 5.1 mix, it is simulated and sounds terrible. Stick with the PCM stereo track, it sounds fantastic.I won't comment much on the content of the videos. They are some of the most famous and influential music videos ever made. This is classic stuff. With the exception of Justify My Love (see below) all of the videos are uncut.Now on to the picture quality...what the hell happened here? It's not as horrible as some people have claimed, but it is WAY below standard. There are serious compression artifacts throughout all of the videos. Pixellation, smearing, graininess, blotchy color, blurring, interlacing artifacts. It's all there and it looks bad. I am watching the DVD on an upscaling Blu Ray player on a 52" LCD 1080P television. It won't look as bad on a smaller TV, but it still won't look great. I have honestly seen VHS look better than some of the videos. The Immaculate Collection DVD, which was made from a 19 year old master, looks better.The problem is that someone made the really, really stupid decision to use single layer DVDs instead of the industry standard dual layer DVDs. I suspect this decision was made late in the process to save a few cents and the program was re-compressed to fit in half the space. There is too much compression and too much picture quality lost. I'll bet the original master was for 2 dual layer DVDs and it probably looked very good. It is hard to believe that anyone at Warner quality control approved the picture quality on these DVDs. Didn't Madonna sign off on a release copy??I thought it might have something to do with the age of some of the videos, but the most recent ones look just as bad. The brand new Celebration video only looks slightly better than VHS quality. And it is ridiculous that the widescreen videos are not in 16:9 format, even the recent ones filmed in 16:9 HD are in letterboxed 4:3.There really is no excuse for this to happen, especially from a company as large as Warner and an artist as big as Madonna. Using single layer DVDs could have only saved them a few cents. On a $30 set, that is inexcusable.I would strongly suggest not buying this DVD until Warner addresses the situation. I think outcry among the fans will (hopefully) cause Warner to do the right thing and release a corrected version on dual layer discs.UPDATE - One more thing, the video for Justify My Love is CENSORED! This video was widely released uncensored as a video single in 1991 and sold millions of copies. And NOW, 18 years later, it is censored?? Just unbelievable.Also, the Amazon description claiming the DVD has "unedited and never before seen footage of 'Justify My Love'" is completely false. There is no new footage at all. In fact, you actually see less because of the censorship.If I could split my rating, it would be 4 stars for content and 1 star for quality.
summary: Substandard picture quality and censorship ruin this DVD
Title: N/A

reviewText: I will tell you that I was really scared purchasing this dvd set after reading several negative reviews. Common sense then dawned on me. Amazon and other major retailers are NOT going to sell us a substandard dvd! No retailer would get away with that. I am happy to say that my instinct was right. This collection is by far one of the best video collections ever made and for the perfect LOW price. The 2 disc set is in beautiful picture quality as well as crisp audio (there are two different audio settings so select the one that works for you) and I'm watching it on a 42" HDTV tv set that is less than a year old. I really don't know if the reviewers are smoking something funny or if they are just out to sabotage Madonna's sales.As listed, we are getting 47 of her music videos...ALMOST her entire collection so far in her career. "Drowned World", "Bad Girl", "Oh Father" are left out BUT are still available on her Immaculate Collection and Greatest Hits 1993 to 1999 dvd collections. These are still available to purchase so it makes good business sense to give people a reason to purchase older dvds. Unfortunately "This Used To Be My Playground" (special feature for "A League Of Their Own" film) and the original version of "American Life" are unavailable to us here but that would be the only MINOR flaws of this collection. Don't be afraid to buy this. Please ignore these people. I think they have been brainwashed by the "High definition" industry by believing everything is below standard when in reality, its just as great as it ever was.
summary: Stop the Sabotaging, This Set is INCREDIBLE!

reviewText: No, I'm not knocking off stars because of missing videos. While I'm sad not to see Bad Girl or the MTV Vogue performance that made it onto the Immaculate Collection, it's not the end of the world since I purchased her previous video collections way back when. This release gets only three stars (and seriously, I'm considering dropping it down to two) because the content looks hideous on an HD tv. I would expect the older stuff (Borderline, Material Girl, etc.) to look a little worse for wear since the technology has come a long way since, but Human Nature? You'll See? Don't Tell Me? They look equally bad to the point where I double checked my HDMI connection and tried popping in another disc to see if my hardware was the problem. Nope - the problem is how both dvds were encoded, i.e. BADLY. Apparently no one at Warner Video has ever heard of an anamorphic transfer. We get forced 4:3 and pixelation galore.Throw in annoying menus (you have to page through multiple screens to select videos from a simple list) and I'm beginning to forget why I wanted this collection in the first place. Madonna has some great videos, but this set is no reason to celebrate. If you have her earlier collections, skip this one and wait for Warner Video to get it right when they no doubt release a mega-set or "complete works" at some later date.*edited to add*Almost forgot - and I should really take a star off for this - they censored Justify My Love. I also suspect Erotica was  altered as I don't remember some of the scenes being so blurry.
summary: Love Madonna, but this is a slapdash job by Warner Bros. Video

Apparently WB were too cheap to put out a BR version-probably for the best as they know mobs of angry 1080p fans with 40 inch screens would march upon and burn WB HQ to the ground-as the sick job they did would become evenMORE evident onscreenNB: Apparently there is a one disc version in Japan-im sure it is no betterSo instead of giving MADONNA a 21 gun salute farewell-as she has made them BILLIONS OF DOLLARS-they give her a one squirt water pistol saluteIt would have been less expensive for them and more honest to just say "Eff-you Madonna-dont let the door hi yer ass on the way out of Warner HQ"And "Hmm.........yeah-we can still bilk her fans out of millions of dollars by doing the bare minimum in effort in a send off package!"Also, to save a buck, all discs for all territories worldwide where made by WMME in Germany (Warner Music Manufacturing Europe)These discs take home video back to the prehistoric era-and where not crafted for HD or BR in any way shape or form-in other wordsnot looking at 2010 and beyond they chose pre 2000 VHS qualityI am not really much of a MADONNA fan at all-but when i heard of this I knew it was wrong because of the greed factorMADONNA is an icon in music history, is likely a decent if shrewd person and an amazing artist. More to the pointShe has made Warner Bros BILLIONS-maybe trillions of dollars;What a shiitty way for WMG to say "Thank you for all your years here at WB-Maddy"

reviewText: Let's face it without music videos Madonna's music career would not have been what it is today. When I first heard Warner Bros. were doing a retrospective of her career by releasing Celebration, I felt a good video collection would be indispensable. Then would I heard it was going to be a double cd and a double dvd release, I actually was beginning to really look forward to it.I'm going to say bluntly that Warner Bros. missed their chance to release a tight comprehensive collection here. I understand putting Madonna's 20 plus years of making music into one release is quite a feat! But this could've have been better selected. My question is where is the logic to leaving out Oh Father and Bad Girl!? Both videos are brilliantly done and even the naysayers would have to agree with that. What's the point of dropping those and leaving in the more cute but forgettable videos like Love Profusion and Get Together?! And don't even get me started on the censorship that was placed on the Justify My Love video! For an artist who stood up to censorship almost her whole career...it's blasphemy!But in the end, it's a fine way to remember why we were once head over heels for this woman and that raw artistic sensibility we just couldn't deny.Much respect to Madonna!
summary: A good attempt by Warner Bros.

reviewText: Talk about a colossal letdown!!  When I slipped disc one into my Blu-Ray player, with the upscaling I was expecting near pristine picture quality due to the fact that this collection was advertised as "remastered". That was a big fat lie!! Most of the videos looked OK-ish, not great, on disc one. The quality seemed to equal that of her previous video collections if not a tad worse. Disc two? Complete and total crapola!  I Want You looked as if someone taped it from TV. Blurry, grainy, AWFUL! I was also shocked that Human Nature and most of the others looked worse than on previous collections. Material Girl even popped and skipped in two places. I played it back twice to make sure I wasn't crazy. As mentioned countless times before, JML is freakin censored. I also believe Erotica is as well. Can't be sure since I have nothing to compare it to from a previous collection. Warner Bros should hang their heads shame for releasing such a piss poor product. I'm sure they don't give a rat's ass.All that said however, let me touch on a few positive things about the collection.1. Express Yourself comes in it's full form with the full 5 minute Shep Pettibone remix.2. We get Who's That Girl, Into The Groove, True Blue and Live To Tell among others.I just can't believe that after all this time Warner Bros would do this to Madonna fans. All the great years she's had with them and they release this? Shame shame shame!! I want my money back!!

reviewText: The video quality is on par with the how these videos were produced mostly back in the 80's and 90's and look better on this DVD than when they aired on broadcast TV. I'm running the sound through my stereo receiver and it sounds great. Glad I bought this collection and didn't listen to the bad reviews. Excellent collection of a music career spanning decades. If you're a Madonna fan, you will appreciate this collection. Not sure why the black censor bars show up in Justify My Love. This had to be a Corporate decision by Warner, but aren't most of Madonna fans all grown up now? The video is still pretty raunchy even with censorship. Remember MTV was mostly concerned with the video's "tone" than the content. Overall, this collection is like a love letter from Madge. Recommended.

reviewText: Well, let's cut to it:PRESENTATION:PLAIN HORRIBLE! what is it with Madonna and her videos? the art is horrible! the paper is so bad quality that when I received mine and opened, I really thought this was an illegal copy like the ones you can get on the street. So many artist release their videos in such great presentations and menus, some special features will have been greatly appreciated to really CELEBRATE, behind the scenes, interviews or special presentations like the MTV Vogue that you can find in the Immaculate collection version.THE SOUND:it's OK, just O-K! it sounds better than Immaculate collection, it does, but is still unforgivable that there is no DTS track or a REAL 5.1.THE CONTENT:It is fabulous to seat down a see all this videos together and experience how Madonna has come all the way with her music and artistic expression. I enjoyed a lot, but.... how can 2 of the more stylish of her videos be missing like OH FATHER, DROWNED WORLD and NOTHING REALLY MATTERS, this is NOT a complete collection, PERIOD.THE QUALITY:If you pop immaculate collection on your DVD and compare the image, you will see ( with a sharp eye ) there is a small boost in image quality, but really, is this the best they could come up with.FINAL THOUGHTS:This just feels like a poor product with no consideration to the fans, not any effort to make a quality DVD on the level of the queen of pop, and is sad to feel Madonna doesn't really works as hard as in her concerts or her music, on the media released to he public. I wish she really learn from Bjork on this.The 3 stars are because I appreciate some videos not released before on DVD, and the rush I had watching them,but, this is simply..... an insult product for a Madonna fan,an O-K product for a casual Madonna buyer.

reviewText: Come on all you Warner honeys, black stripes blocking female body parts? I never laughed so hard as when the dominatrix from Justify my Love walked in or when Madonna was hitchhiking starkers in Erotica. This one is a must keep! It's a classic filled with unintentional hilarity!You've got to admit - this collection is by far the most comprehensive with 47 clips. Making their long overdue appearance on a Madonna video collection are Into The Groove, True Blue, Live To Tell, Who's That Girl and I'll Remember. Obviously, Warner did not include everything, otherwise The Immaculate Collection and  93:99 will be obsolete. I know, it's more convenient to have everything in one package.What's with Celebration? The old crotch grabbing Madonna looking like Gwen Stefani hanging out with people younger than her by 20 years. The plus side is that this version of Celebration is different from the audio counterpart.The videos for This Used To Be My Playground, Dear Jessie and Everybody never made it to any Madonna DVD. (Or has it?). There are no official videos for Dress You Up, Causing A Commotion, Hanky Panky and Bye Bye Baby. So concert footage was used to promote these singles. A very curious omission is American Life. My guess is that Madonna did not want to offend the Bush Administration. But she has no problems taking liberties with religion because she knows that God is merciful.I am also waiting to see if a compilation of Madonna's MTV and other TV performances will be issued.My made in Singapore Celebration DVD is loud and clear in terms of sound. The picture quality is excellent. However, I can understand the complaints. I have some US DVDs. The audio is terribly soft and you have to turn the volume to full blast. Sometimes, the picture is rather fuzzy too.Still in terms of content, Madonna Celebration beats the others hands down. The inner liner note doubles as a poster. So get it before it goes out of print!

reviewText: Madonna has defined the MTV music video with her stylish and provocative button pushing. She has crafted more videos than any other female artist, she has earned the most MTV vma nominations, and has won the most MTV vmas of any artist. This collection shows how this one women force known simply as Madonna has impacted music, and with the music video created a whole new art form that forced every artist after her to realize a music video was just as important as the song itself. From her first video Everybody to her latest video Celebration, Madonna has been a constant on our radar for over 26 years and has grown up and evolved in front of all of us. Madonna pushed buttons with what she could get away with in a music video. Vogue had her exposing her breasts in a see through blouse which caused MTV to ask her to take the scene out, but Madonna refused and MTV eventually gave in, and had their first video showing nudity airing all hours of the day. Madonna pushed the boundaries a little too far with her next video and MTV did not give in to her Justify My Love video. MTV banned it all together because of its gay themes and her making out with another women far before girl on girl action became the in thing. Erotica pushed the boundaries a bit further as Madonna released her SEX book which had her naked from head to toe and expressing her sexual fantasies. The video Erotica was only aired 3 times on MTV and (with a disclaimer) that was after 12 midnight due to the sexual nature, and a Madonna hitchhiking nude scene at the very end. The What It Feels Like For A Girl video was released and MTV only played it one time before banning it completely due to its violent nature which was something we had never seen from Madonna. Her most controversial music video (and rarely seen) was the original version of American Life which came out when we had just went to war with Iraq. Madonna did something she had never done before and that was pulling the video right before its world premiere (due to death threats on her kids) on MTV and VH1. The video which took place on a runway and simulated war with people getting body parts blown up, along with a George Bush look a like kissing Saddam Hussein on the cheek. These are some of the music video highlights in Madonnas ever evolving music video career. Sadly like other artists before her, her art will not be fully be appreciated or understood until she is gone. Only then will people discover how ahead of her time and how truly visionary and what a work of art she was as herself.Below is courtesy of [...]Warner Bros. Records has confirmed in a press release the final track listing for Madonna's upcoming "Celebration the Video Collection DVD". The 2 disc set will also include unedited and never before seen footage of the "Justify My Love" video along with 27 Madonna videos to be released on a DVD compilation for "the very first time" including "Into The Groove" from Desperately Seeking Susan and "Give It To Me" as well as the just completed video of Madonna's new single "Celebration".Madonna Celebration DVD Track Listing:1) Burning Up - First Time On DVD2) Lucky Star3) Borderline4) Like A Virgin5) Material Girl6) Crazy For You - First Time On DVD7) Into The Groove - First Time On DVD8) Live To Tell - First Time On DVD9) Papa Don't Preach10) True Blue - First Time On DVD11) Open Your Heart12) La Isla Bonita13) Who's That Girl - First Time On DVD14) Like A Prayer15) Express Yourself16) Cherish17) Vogue18) Justify My Love - First Time On DVD19) Erotica - First Time On DVD20) Deeper and Deeper - First Time On DVD21) Rain22) I'll Remember - First Time On DVD23) Secret24) Take A Bow25) Bedtime Story26) Human Nature27) I Want You - First Time On DVD28) You'll See - First Time On DVD29) Frozen30) Ray Of Light31) The Power Of Good-Bye32) Beautiful Stranger33) American Pie - First Time On Madonna DVD34) Music35) Don't Tell Me - First Time On DVD36) What It Feels Like For A Girl37) Die Another Day - First Time On Madonna DVD38) Hollywood - First Time On DVD39) Love Profusion - First Time On DVD40) Hung Up41) Sorry42) Get Together - First Time On DVD43) Jump - First Time On DVD44) 4 Minutes - First Time On DVD45) Give It 2 Me - First Time On DVD46) Miles Away - First Time On DVD47) Celebration - First Time On DVDOther popular videos that didn't make the final cut on this new compilation, like David Fincher's Oh Father and Bad Girl, Nothing Really Matters, Love Don't Live Here Anymore and Fever, remain available on Madonna's current best selling DVD releases The Immaculate Collection and Video Collection 93:99.
summary: Madonna Artpop at its best! Pop art often imitated but never duplicated!

reviewText: I grew up as a Madonna fan, watching her in the early days of MTV and waiting for her music videos to show up on rotation on public access TV where I could watch videos for "Burning Up" and "Everybody". When this video collection was announced, I thought it was a great idea. Even though I have both of her previously released video collections, I immediately pre-ordered this collection.Boy, was I in for a disappointment. Don't get me wrong, there are a lot of good videos on this collection, but for heaven's sake a CENSORED version of "Justify My Love"?The regular version of "True Blue" without the MTV viewer video? That contest was advertised for MONTHS on MTV back in the day and would have been an excellent inclusion.No "Drowned World/Substitute for Love", which is not only a great song/video, but virtually an explanation of Madonna's transformation from her early years to her current career?I love many of these videos, but this could and should have been a better compilation.  Madge deserved it and so do her loyal fans.
Title: N/A

reviewText: In the days where MTV is playing pimps being lapdanced by topless strippers, Madonna releases her video collection with a censored version of Justify My Love and Erotica.Once upon a time Madonna swore over and over she would rather cancel shows rather than change them or censor her videos.Well apparently she's become even greedier with age because the "never seen footage of Justify My Love" that was taunted pre-release is nothing more but a black stripe covering the dominatrix's nipples in the video! And Erotica has no nudity.So, I don't understand WHY she is realeasing two versions of this dvd collection, one in amaray case and one in digipack. Who wants that? Why not do something really smart and at least do one of those with a friggin' parental advisory sticker and give the grown-up fans what she knows they wanted?Hopefully now that Madonna is no longer with Warner Bros they will milk her catalogue like a cow  and release everything she's done and not care about this unspoken rule of "always keep some things unreleased so we can milk the fans in the future!".My balls hit the floor when I saw that black stripe on Justify My Love.
summary: Madonna has lost her edge. Censored videos!

reviewText: "Madonna Celebration: The Video Collection" is a fantastic 2 dvd set that showcases various songs from her successful career (22 music videos for disc 1 and 25 for disc 2).  At the time of this writing, Amazon US does not yet list all of the songs on both dvds but you can click on the second customer image for the complete listing. Currently, Amazon Germany would also be the place to go for the full video listing of both dvds. I chose to watch these music videos in order to get ready for Madonna's concert tonight. "Burning Up", "Cherish", and "Vogue" are among the videos on disc one that represent the early 1980's to the middle 1990's. Then, there is  "Ray of Light", "Music", "Love Profusion", and "4 Minutes" on disc two to represent the 1990's to the 2000's. "Vogue" and "Jump" are currently two of my favorite songs and music videos from these dvd sets. "Madonna Celebration: The Video Collection" is best for Madonna fans and/or those who like at least seven Madonna songs.

reviewText: I would not recommend purchasing this DVD. The picture quality is terrible. I have the 93-99 collection on DVD, which shares some of the same videos. The difference in quality is pronounced. This DVD has a grainy picture quality that would be surpassed by VHS. What a disappointment. These are some of the most notable videos in the history of music videos. They deserve a much better treatment. Hopefully a remastered video collection will be released at some point in the future.

reviewText: I pre-ordered this dvd and I still have to get my copy from Amazon but I bought the Philippine version just this past weekend. It has the same tracklist and it contains a fold-out poster (similar to that of the cd) and notes at the back on who produced and directed each video. Admittedly, I was sort of influenced and disappointed by some bad reviews over the alleged sub-standard picture quality so I was prepared for anything. But when I first saw it, I loved the packaging (it was not placed in the standard dvd container but in a cd-type package). I went home and braced myself for a video experience which could either be great or lousy. I put the dvd in my Sony player (which I connnected to my Sony amplifier for great sound) and watched it on my Sony TV. Lo and behold! The experience was a wonderful and nostalgic trip down memory lane. As I was viewing each video, I was reliving my life for the past 25 years and realized that Madonna was there during each phase of my life because she had such a great and lasting impact on me through her wonderful music - starting in the 80s when I was a naive college student up to now in the 00s when I am working in the corporate world. As I said in my review of the cd, Madonna has artistically and musically evolved through the years. The chronological sequence (which I hoped they had done with the cd) in this dvd was perfect because it showed the changes in Madonna (her looks, video concepts, types of music) through the 25 years of her sterling career as an artist. From "Burning Up" which starts the video experience all the way to her most recent video "Celebration" which ends the double dvd - boy it was such a magnificent audio-visual experience! Madonna was so different yet beautiful in all her videos. Her chameleon-like changes in each video was really a lesson in brilliant reinvention - one of the reasons for her career longevity. She truly deserves the honor of being named MTV's Artist of the Millenium. The picture and sound quality were perfect (at least viewing it with my Sony equipment) so I don't know what all that pixellation and smearing fuss was all about. For all the readers, please get a copy of this double dvd because it is the definitive Madonna compilation. With 47 videos, this is indeed a must-own because it is one great video after another. I don't see why there are others who choose to be so negative. Who cares if "Justify" was censored? You can always play the uncensored version from your collection. However, I had hoped they made it 50 videos for this compilation (at 25 videos per disc) and included "This Used to be My Playground," "Nothing Really Matters," "Fever," or "Bad Girl." The last 3 are among her best. For all the fans, please go out and support Madonna because she is our Queen of Pop. Other artists sound and look irritatingly the same which makes them boring and redundant but not our Madonna who always sees change as a step forward and in the right direction. I am disappointed that American radio has not played "Celebration" which is a great and positive song nor her past few singles which is the reason they have not done well in the Billboard Hot 100 (Hung Up was no. 1 in 47 countries EXCEPT the US!). I hope that "Revolver" gets better treatment because it has a different vibe compared to other Madonna songs. Madonna is a great American artist and a pop icon so I am wondering (more of in extreme bewilderment) why she is not being given anymore the massive support she previously enjoyed and so rightfully deserves in her mother country. I must give the wonderful British people so much commendation because they simply love Madonna and have, in fact, made Madonna their Queen with 13 no. 1 songs and 11 no. 1 albums (Celebration was her 11th No. 1 album in the UK). Noteworthy, their King also happens to be American - Elvis Presley. Surprisingly, other artists who are big in America are only big in America and are not given much attention in Britain or outside America. Madonna is the true GLOBAL SUPERSTAR because she is loved everywhere from Asia to Europe. Her music is universal and appeals to everyone regardless of age, color or gender. Cheers to Madonna! Here's to the next chapter of your illustrious music career inspiring people with your brand of great pop music. I must also mention that Madonna's control of her personal life is inspiring to her fans and worth emulating - no drugs, no alcohol, no breakdowns, no scandals. All the best to Her Madgesty :-)
summary: THE CELEBRATION DVD IS A MUST-OWN VIDEO COLLECTION !!!
